author: Vandill
title: Pretty sad response time from Google
content:
This is a pretty good app by Google. Currently there is a problem that I\'m seeing with badge notifications not properly updating.  I\'ve tried to remove the app from my phone and reinstall it but that didn\'t solve the issue.  Started with iOS11 so I\'m guessing it is related. I would like an option to mark something as read from the notification screen instead of, or in addition to archiving. Maybe I\'m alone in this but I don\'t really use the archive feature.  Anyway, 3 stars until the badges issue is resolved.  It lets you check your email so it does its job. Nothing flashy or special.  Like most of Google\'s apps.  It\'s functional which is good enough.

Dropping rating to 1 star and uninstalling in a week if Google, one of the biggest tech companies in the world, can\'t fix a notification bug.  I mean come on. I\'m guessing that at least 1 guys job at Google is to care about the app working. Even if it\'s just 1 guy he could have already fixed this in a day.  Get it together.  We give you all our private information willingly and you can\'t have a guy fix the red badge that a 13 year old kid that is learning to make apps for the first time can edit and change?

author: Dpw1461
title: Can’t find old emails
content:
I’m a member of a fairly large Google Group, which uses Gmail to communicate.  We have h HUGE issue with people not realizing they’ve missed an important email because Gmail nests emails with the same subject.  If you get several responses to an announcement by users who “Reply All”, the main topic  gets buried under the comments.

Then we get a rash of complaints by members claiming they never received the announcement. If I search for it, I can’t find it unless I remember the subject line verbatim.  You can’t change this nesting feature on the mobile platforms.  If this could be changed, Gmail would be much more useful to us.

title: Only use it for the labels
content:
This is the only app I’ve found that supports Gmail’s labeling system, so this is what I use on my phone. There are so many things that I wish I did better - like scheduling emails, getting notified for important emails only, more customization, etc. 

But right now, the most *obnoxious* thing is that the notification bubbles don’t go away! I’ll read all of my emails, sort them, and close out Gmail, and it’ll still show the old number of unread emails for the next couple hours. It never clears out the notification bubble - it just updates the next time I get new emails. As someone who likes to clear out all of the badges numbers on my phone, it’s infuriating! 

I would switch clients in a heartbeat if they worked with Gmail’s labeling system.

author: bx01z
title: Too Much Like the Website Version
content:
I know, it may sound ridiculous, but the mobile app is too much like the desktop/website version. This was not built to be optimized for the mobile phone. It has all the controls on the top which makes one hand email handling difficult. You have to change between accounts to check each email address (I have 4 through gmail and gsuite). There no fingerprint lock, no snooze option, and little customization. I would prefer to have all my email on one view as an option. 

Other apps like Spark, Inbox and even Outlook offer these features. 

The reason I have to use this app is because of the incredibly slow load time for gmail messages into third-party apps. It’s not all the time, but it’s frequent enough to be annoying where content takes minutes to load. 

It’s frustrating being between a rock and a hard place with an interface I’d prefer on another app that takes too long to load gmail messages. It works fine for gsuite and non-gmail accounts. I would love to use one app for all email and wouldn’t mind the Google app if it was a bit friendlier for mobile and didn’t require so much navigation.

author: Zoltani
title: Still terrible
content:
Honestly, I think Google's updates amount to little more than review fraud. They've continually hit the reset button on overwhelmingly 1 star reviews by "updating" the app, yet hardly any of the updates have addressed the complaints which are largely macro issues. As a whole, it's still bad, and the one star reviewers are simply giving up on having to resubmit their reviews after each update. And look at the 5 star reviews - largely substance-free generic praise. I doubt most of them. Don't believe the 3+ star average. 

This app is a visual assault. It's hard to get past the nausea inducing aesthetics. Fewer emails to see at a glance, pointless avatars, ugh, the red! The check box was MUCH more intuitive than the initials/avatar circle that have replaced it. It's simply harder to read and process at a glance. 

Why did you bury the reply button? Most often, what I want to reply to is at the top. I shouldn't have to scroll down to reply. In general things that were intuitive aren't. It's not my job to figure this stuff out. It's your job to design it so I don't have to. 

This update is terrible all around. A mess. No amount of tweaks will save this update. Revert to the previous version. Really. It's that awful. And again, I don't believe the majority of the 5 star reviews.

author: Guide Dragon
title: I used to really like this app
content: I used to really like this app. My work uses GSUITE, and I have all of my other e-mail imported into my perstonal Gmail. I am a blind user who uses the iPhone's native Braille screen input feature to perform 95% of text entry. About two weeks ago, I noticed that using Gmail with the onscreen Braille keyboard resulted in words without spaces... This is really inconvenient because, in addition to the problems it causes with e-mail, I've integrated 90% of my digital life into the GoogleVerse, including Calendar and Docs. I have reported this issue, and I am told they are working on it, but I wanted perspective users to be aware in the meantime.

author: FrenchMonkey
title: Mostly Good
content: Most of my opinions on Gmail app for iOS are good. I'm a mostly Mac/iPhone/iPad person in a PC/Android world. I prefer the Google set of apps because it allows me to maneuver a bit better in this dichotomy. Also I like the material design on the Google apps better. The Gmail app specifically needs improvement in viewing previous replies, especially those that come in while you might be replying. I often miss replies because of the way responses are displayed. In the app it's very difficult to figure out who replied when during an active conversation that often includes more than two responders. I do like how social and promotion emails are separated, although I'd prefer to tweak those settings. There very well may be a control but it's not obvious if there is, nor have I gone looking.

author: Not Tin Zaw
title: No custom notification sound
content: One cannot choose a unique notification sound for each and every app in iOS. The fruit company leaves it to the app maker to facilitate the choice of notification sound. The app maker should include a feature in the app’s “preferences” or “settings” to allow users to pick the notification tone of their choice. Otherwise, the way it is, it is just another “ding” when an email comes in via Gmail. (iOS only recognizes emails coming in via its native mail app as incoming emails to trigger incoming email alert tone set in the iPhone’s settings.)

author: baiji888
title: Evolution to unusable
content: A real step down from v4. I’ve been clinging to v4 since v5 was foisted on us almost a year ago.  Unfortunately, iOS 11 broke v4. So here we go... Ridiculous amount of wasted space in user interface. Who decided that “modern” app layout aesthetic is as much unused white space as possible, to the point where app usability is seriously degraded? (I’m also talking to you, iOS 11 App Store.) Why does even a basic productivity app have to be turned into an “experience” at the expense of productivity? (I’m also talking to you, latest iOS version of Skype app.) Wish I could see more than 5 email summaries at a time in Inbox. Huge red banner makes me feel angry and violent about my email. Why did gmail get saddled with suckiest of google logo colors? Also: STOP LOADING REMOTE IMAGES BY DEFAULT!

content: I’ve been using this app for many years and have had no trouble adapting to many of its changes and updates, but this latest update caused a very annoying issue, which I really hope gets fixed soon. author: SHWTD
title: Simple and clean
content:
I had to find a replacement for Apple mail that is not strong enough to prevent serious glitches, and using gmail for both my personal and business emails, this app came recommended by a friend with the same predicament. 

This app is fluid, gets the emails faster than Mail, allows to manage several email accounts and can pretty much do everything in a few taps. It connects easily with both Safari or Chrome when you open links. 

In the nitpicking section of this review there is :
- Some additional gestures could be added to make things a bit faster and more intuitive.
- The red and white Google design chart is a bit too Android (I said it was the nitpicking section).

All in all a very nice alternative to Apple Mail that never did the job perfectly. You will lose some connectivity with Contacts for example but it’s easy to copy/paste.

author: Artappstore
title: Best mail app in a weak field - could be awesome
content:
I’ve tried every mail app out there and while some have better features than gmail (snooze messages, Dropbox integration) most of them have fatal flaws around performance, reliability of syncing message or search changes that render them unusable- including apple’s iOS mail client. Gmail is the best of the field because it is fast and the most reliable. 

That said, it has a few things I’d love to see addressed to make it 5 stars:

1) Freezing - the app occasionally hangs on the message list page, especially when going from landscape to portrait mode. Sometimes it recovers, other times you have to kill it. My guess is that it’s doing a remote call and the UI is waiting on it to finish when it shouldn’t be

2) drilling into the to and from fields. Apple iOS makes this easy - you can click someone’s name to find their phone number from you contacts and call or text them. 

3) replying or forwarding specific threads in messages is cumbersome. Gmail buries this action in an ellipsis when it needs its own small icon. Apples iOS app does this well

4) unified inbox, starred and sent messages for multiple accounts - all the other apps do this well

5) message snoozing - outlook for iOS and mail (fka gladly do) do this well

6) Dropbox integration for file attachments

author: MHCounselor
title: VERY GOOD - BUT....
content:
I only give 4 stars, but could easily go to 5 with a small feature added. 

I've been using the Gmail app from the beginning after I got my first smart phone - first an android, now an iPhone. I have loved this app and it's multiple features that replicate using the desktop - making this app No#1 in my book for many years - until now. 

Many of the other email apps have added "privacy" step by adding the option of Touch ID to open. This feature is something that I would love to see Google incorporate into this app. 

I manage several gmail accounts-business and personal. Though my phone itself is password locked, there are times that a family member or friend has asked to use my phone to make a quick call or search for something, which means that my gmail is accessible (if they were so inclined to snoop). Touch ID would provide me extra security to my gmail (especially my business email account, which can contain sensitive information or documents) as well as give me some extra piece of mind when my phone is unlocked. 

Is adding this feature something that is forthcoming?  If not, then I feel that I need to find an alternative app for my gmail accounts. 

You Touch ID isn't something you're concerned with, then this app is the way to go in managing your gmail.

author: Derpyhoof123
title: Complained and had my problem fixed in just two weeks
content:
I’m legally blind and I had been hearing from my friends that this was a much better app than apple’s mail system so I got it. Not minutes after I was busy sending out an angry email to some poor “help and feedback” facilitator about how their “adapt to iphone text size” option doesnt work. I angrily told them that If this is not fixed they have lost me as a customer Because their app is useless to me if i can’t see anything.
   Now bear in mind, I wasn’t expecting anything to come from it. I figured, like most multimillion dollar companies, my complaint would be ignored along side many others. But, instead of being ignored I found that within two weeks they released an update that fully fixed the problem and only my problem. Within two weeks the developers made the app go from impossible to use to being easily the best email app out there. They have earned my respect and gratitude as a customer. 
    If you want a great email app that notifies you when, and only when, the most important emails come through, helps you archive, prioritize and organize your emails and provides an enviorment where you can ensure your biggest problems will be handled with care and efficiency than gmail is the app for you.
(This is not sponsored in any way, I just had to express my gratitude for this recent update. If you know someone who worked on this update please give them a giant hug for me)

author: OlasOrtwein
title: FIX THE NOTIFICATION BADGES - too much extra sh*t
content:
Idk if it’s an iOS thing, or just the app; but this issue has always been a problem. I’d much rather use the Gmail app than the general Mail app, but when it says I have x-amount of unread messages - even though I’ve gone through all of my accounts tens of times and don’t actually have any unread messages - it makes me want to go back to hotmail or something else that’s very-early-2000s. It shouldn’t be that hard to correctly show how many unread messages I have (or in this case don’t have).

Also, idk who or what app started the excess swiping/tapping nonsense; but half of the time I try to delete some spam mail, it ends up being archived to some folder I have extremely limited access to, or it opens up because the room for error for selecting these emails is slimmer than a flappy bird.

I’m “only” 26, but these over complicated apps make me feel like I may as well be living in an old-folks home.

author: cpoagsc
title: No Connection errors
content:
Revision: I’m an idiot and this app is great. The reason I had trouble with the app when not on WiFi was because data was turned off for the app in my phone’s settings. Changed my low rating to a 5-star.

This app is completely useless for me on iPhone. It never connects and reports \"no connection\" at the bottom of the screen while every other app on the phone has no trouble connecting. It is only this app that has problems connecting. I\'ve followed all help and forum posts I\'ve found and they\'re pretty useless. I\'ve logged out and back in (sometimes it won\'t even let me log back in, giving me the \"no connection\" error). I\'ve deleted and reinstalled the app many times with no success. And yes, Google, I\'m sure I\'m using the correct password.

Google needs to resolve the \"no connection\" error issue with an update rather than just advising people to check their password or make sure they\'re connected to the internet (when every other app on the device works fine).

When I receive an email, I get the red badge in the top right corner of the app’s icon (like all app notifications). HOWEVER, when I check my email and clear out the unread emails, the badge doesn’t go away. Not only is this SEVERELY annoying as I prefer to maintain a clean home screen, it causes me to check my email when unnecessary. This usually means using data and time that is clearly not needed as I don’t have unread emails. 

I do like the functionality of the app, but I will not continue to use an app that creates unnecessary thought and slows productivity. To me, that is unacceptable and not the point. I humbly ask that Google fix this error or I will be forced to delete the app and go back to using the Apple Mail app.

author: sethlong
title: Lacks essential iOS productivity functions
content:
The app is, overall, fine. Google’s Material UI looks out of place on iOS but that’s not the end of the world.

What IS a big deal, though, is the complete lack of support for iPad’s split-screen and slideover features. This could be overlooked if these were new features in iOS, but they aren’t. 

At all. 

Other Google apps, like Docs and Sheets, support these modes (though it was a long wait) and it’s really inexcusable that Gmail doesn’t. 

The app also doesn’t have a watchOS version, which means that Gmail users have to resort to using Mail.app or a 3rd party mail app to use a Gmail account on watchOS. 

Finally, the swipe actions in message list views aren’t configurable like the ones in other mail clients. Swiping left or right on a message offers the exact same single action, rather than several. Yes, you can set that single action to be either delete or archive, but users can’t expose a menu of choices like they can in Spark or even Mail.app. 

These missing features prevent Gmail from being a truly great productivity app for Apple users.

author: Tokyo bound
title: Missing basic functions
content: I swiped on an email heading and the email disappeared. It never told me what it was doing with the email. Did it delete it? Did it archive it? Did it forward it to my grandma? I had no idea. So I looked for the undo button. Oh, there ISN\'T one. I shook the phone, which works in EVERY OTHER APP, it\'s a basic iPhone function. Nope. That didn\'t work either. I found the email still there under \"All Mail\" but there was no way to undo the archive and put it back into my primary folder, at least no way that was immediately intuitive. So that was super frustrating. Also, there is no \"mark unread from here\" in an email conversation. So if I mark something as unread, the entire email chain gets marked as unread. This is ridiculous. I sometimes have conversations with clients that have 50 emails back and forth. I don\'t want to have to go through them all again. Unfortunately, the built-in iPhone mail app does the same thing. But at least it has an undo function. I have gotten to where I rarely check email on my phone because there isn\'t yet a good app to deal with it. It used to be simple and it used to work. Now with all the folders and functions, replacing basic functionality, it just makes it a pain. Companies always try to fix things that aren\'t broken and just break them in the process. So this app is deleted. And I will go back to using the iPhone mail app to scan the previews and go to my Mac to actually reply.

title: NEW VERSION IS FRUSTRATING!
content: I procrastinated updating to the new style version for months, because I depended heavily on this app and loved it. I finally caved and have been using it for about a month now. And it just frustrates me! The badge notification for new mail doesn\'t always go away after all messages are read. Adding attachments is cumbersome now; it automatically imbeds them in your message and you have to individually select each to make it an actual attachment - and the app always freezes; I have to close it out and reopen it to get them attached properly. The option of \"mark as unread/read\" no longer exists (SINCERELY miss that). Also, if I open a new email from iPhone\'s drop-down notifications (banner), I can read it in the gmail app fine - but the app keeps it as unread until I re-open the app from the home screen and view the email again. I don\'t get it?! Those are my biggest complaints. I like just being able to swipe to delete, but that convenience isn\'t worth the loss of the other features and the frustration.

There is also no option to select all emails. To me this is inefficient and overly complicated. Other apps I've used simply use a swipe left gesture. In the Gmail app, this gesture archives the mail, cluttering your data storage with unwanted rubbish indefinitely.

title: Reluctant but satisfied
content:
I have been reluctant to add the gmail app to my phone. I kept getting emails from gmail, and then from my phone saying my phone app wouldn't support gmail as well, so I finally switched over. 

It's cool but pretty much what you would expect. Switching between accounts is easy, and while at first I thought the pre-drafted responses they add for you were dumb, they're actually pretty good. Makes replying to emails much easier! 

I do find the ad placement annoying...I honestly feel like gmail should be getting enough data from my usage (and everyone's) that they don't really need ad money, but oh well. I guess you get what you pay for in this case.

I also agree that it would be nice to customize the colors. I'm not sure why they picked red - blue seems to be a major theme in their other products, and red just reminds me of Target. Sorry google, they've had a claim to red for far too long.

author: LeeGeeeeeee
title: Meh
content: I keep trying to like this app and I download it periodically to check it out but after all this time they still lack a key feature, for me at least.  Why the heck don't you have a simple way to do a select all??  This seems like it should be a standard feature.  I don't do a lot of complicated things with email but I do get a lot of them.  I'm a scanner,  I scan through the headings and many times I'm not interested in any of them so I want to get rid of them.  Right now I'm using Airmail.  It's not perfect but it gives me the key features I like.  In airmail all you have to do is select and hold on one of the emails.  At the top of the column in great big letters the "SELECT ALL" option will appear.  After you "SELECT ALL" you then tap on the 3 dots and then can, move, mark as read, trash and a few other options.  Simple.  Why can't Gmail have something similar??

author: Zoltani
title: Still terrible
content:
Honestly, I think Google\'s little updates amount to little more than review fraud. They\'ve continually hit the reset button on overwhelmingly 1 star reviews by \"updating\" the app, yet hardly any of the updates have addressed the complaints which are largely macro issues. As a whole, it\'s still bad, and the one star reviewers are simply giving up on having to resubmit their reviews after each update. And look at the 5 star reviews - largely substance-free generic praise. I doubt most of them. Don\'t believe the 3+ star average. 

This app is a visual assault. It\'s hard to get past the nausea inducing aesthetics. Fewer emails to see at a glance, pointless avatars, ugh, the red! The check box was MUCH more intuitive than the initials/avatar circle that have replaced it. It\'s simply harder to read and process at a glance. 

Why did you bury the reply button? Most often, what I want to reply to is at the top. I shouldn\'t have to scroll down to reply. In general things that were intuitive aren\'t. It\'s not my job to figure this stuff out. It\'s your job to design it so I don\'t have to. 

This update is terrible all around. A mess. No amount of tweaks will save this update. Revert to the previous version. Really. It\'s that awful. And again, I don\'t believe the majority of the 5 star reviews.

author: The Blonde Cookie
title: This rating was SOLICITED in the app
content:
I\'ve already given my thoughts on your app, buuuuuut, since you persist in your shameless solicitation of my rating - I\'ll be happy to knock all the marketing company\'s 5 star (bogus) ratings down a notch. Gmail for computers ~might~ be different, but this review concerns the app. 

The app is MINDLESS. I\'ve subscribed to emails that PERSIST in ending up in my Promotions inbox. I move them, they CONTINUE to show up in the Promotions inbox. I\'ve stopped trying to fight it. I surrender. 

Further, it\'s a PIG - takes up a ridiculous amount of space on my iPhone. 

There should be something in the settings (of the app) where unsolicited emails/spam IMAGES can be set to NOT download on my phone. Seriously - if I \"report it as spam,\" (1) ~WHY~ am I still even seeing it on my phone, (2) if I\'ve reported it as spam, ~WHY~ do I want the RISK of the images on my phone?

I\'ve been online since 1996. This is possibly one of THE most counter-intuitive apps I\'ve ever used. 

That\'s enough for now. Go ahead - ask me to rate your dumb app again. I dare ya. 😈

author: AshlyeeS
title: Complicated for no reason!
content: I used to love gmail. It\'s always been my go to email server. But this past year...maybe even longer...i feel like gmail has really gone out of its way to over complicate something that should stay simple and user friendly. Call me old fashioned and maybe even dumb... but what was so wrong with having just one simple mailbox associated with your ONE email address? My mailbox is just entirely too confusing now. It sorts your mail into 4 different unnecessary (for us common folk)folders... I could understand if you\'re getting hundreds of emails a day but when you\'re just receiving emails from work, family and friends and perhaps emails regarding subscriptions, online receipts and etc I don\'t really see the need for a \"primary\", \"social\", \"promotions\", and \"updates\" folder. Half the time I miss important emails because i just figure they will all show up in my \"primary\" mailbox that is defaulted as the main folder that pops up when I login  and not think to look for them in the \"updates\" or \"promotions\" folder, for instance. I ABSOLUTELY HARE gmail so new format and layout and their whole concept now! If my gmail address wasn\'t over 7 years old and linked to basically my whole life, I\'d delete and switch to yahoo in a heartbeat! 👎👎👎 from me!

title: It use to be great, but it is awful now.
content:
I like Gmail on my computer, but I do not like the mobile app at all. 

I find it very hard to follow, confusing and hard to tell where the newest message is in their string of messages. I cannot tell which part is old email or new email. I much preferred the Gmail mobile app prior to their message stringing system.  I would much prefer that each email message be separate. 

If I try to toss an unnecessary part of a message string, I end up tossing every connected message in the string. 

Also, when I try to reply, it is difficult to know where I should type. There is no line or anything to let me know. 

Google does many thing great, but this Gmail mobile app is not one of them.

author: BrainsLink
title: A great example of Crapware!
content:
Update #2: The app has greatly improved, though very slowly. One major drawback has not been addressed -- email images are always loaded and there is no way to disable the 'feature'. Please be aware that loading images in emails enables advertisers to track you. If you use this app, you will be tracked!
###

Update: Clearly Google is not listening to its user community. They have mangled this app. They are adding features while we loudly complain about a terrible user experience.

Hey Apple -- Please give us the ability to uninstall an app update and return to the prior version!
###

If you currently use the Gmail app, do not install this new version. It is horrible. Completely different, slow, cumbersome, and ugly. Stay away.

author: The Blonde Cookie
title: DUMB app - as in MINDLESS
content:
Since I (reluctantly) started using Gmail, I have found it to be DUMB - as in, it doesn't "learn," regardless of how long I tell it (in essence, since I can't do it in reality) "not spam, belongs in my primary box."  Every stinkin' day I have to move the particular email(s) from "Promotions," to "Primary."  You have something in the drop down menu for "Report Spam," and even "Not Spam."  Can't you insert one that says "Not Promotion," while you're at it. 🤔

Gmail is THE most counter-intuitive, unfriendly email app I've EVER used (I've been online since 1996, and never have used any emails except free ones, due to the portability issue). It's enough to make me use the account to my IOS mailbox. I can't find ANY instructions, directions, or what have you for the Gmail app, and I've looked online. 

And it's a memory hog, too. 

Get a grip, Google. Fix your junk.

author: Northwest Sharma
title: Reliable Reality
content: Until this came up to rate Gmail, I hadn't considered how much it has become central to my personal, professional and philanthropic life. It just works. It is there. And I have come to expect it. There isn't much that I haven't stretched Gmail to do in my life. With a career in consulting, and decades on Outlook, I haven't missed our wondered about functionality. Through Gmail, Google is powering small business and non-profit including education. This is a pretty big deal. As with anything, I wonder if we appreciate the things that come without a price or with a low price? Certainly I can't imagine Gmail 'going away'. I value very much my daily connectivity to all those people that I value.

author: ParkerV
title: The worst client ever
content:
The lack of support for external email providers, contacts, and calendars make this the worst email client available.

It's like Google rolled the clock back 15 years when they designed it.

"Unified inbox" has been the standard for years. You can't even commingle personal and work gmail accounts.

Server works fine. Client makes you want to kill yourself. A walled garden.

author: sMyNickname
title: Needs a lot of work--still--Google, do you read anyone\'s reviews???
content:
Not the most responsive app in the world.

 It\'s a real pain to switch back-and-forth between multiple accounts. Why not just make one inbox with both accounts? 

When I get click on reply or forward and then have to click on the actual message to start typing. This is really stupid and it should automatically bring the keyboard up so I can start typing. 

Signatures need to be at the end of each email.

I can\'t turn conversation with you on or off. The app is still a little buggy and I have to close it and open back up to get it to work.   I can\'t even delete an email from a conversation without delaying the whole stupid thing. It would be really nice if google would actually read the reviews and update the app accordingly!

Really the nicest feature about this is the push notifications! If it wasn\'t for that I would just ditch the app completely and go back to the native iOS app.

author: alollipoppy
title: NEVER update gmail app, Lesson Learned!!!!!
content:
If your app is working well for you, never get tempted by the new bells and whistles promised and update. Chances are some features you love have been tweaked if not discontinued, in trade off for the new nonsense. I made that mistake last night. 

I used to enjoy this app now i'm in a constant state of annoyance whenever I click on a link in my emails, in opens in an in-app browser. When i change the settings to open in Safari, it still opens in the in-app browser and then i have to hit the safari icon on the bottom. This extra step is so unnecessary and oddly time consuming becasue I can't send multiple emails to safari to view later while cleaning out my inbox. This new method FORCES me to view in the in-app browser one email at a time. 

Please fix this!!! The app was great the way it functioned before now i hate it, and have to look elsewhere for a new email app. Never update, lesson learned!!!!

content: Great app, but since my work email, due to HIPAA, is not able to route through most mail apps (I don't want my personal mixing with my professional) I need a breakout app for my 4 maintained Gmail accounts while my work stays on the regular mail app. I had high hopes for this since they were all gmail, however a few aspects that ended up being the deal breaker for me in not being good for long-term use: (1) no option for a consolidated inbox of all your linked emails, similar to how the basic Mail app works on the iPhone (2) I would have loved being able to control notification sounds/alerts more in-depthly (3) No ability to keep the mobile signature above the body of text when replying nor autopopulated when you're writing so you can tweak it before you send.

And one swipe moves emails to \"archive\", but when I looked for an \"archive\" folder,  one was not in the menu. And what does \"archive\" do? So now I have to search for the missing emails.   If I am totally wrong I apologize, but in this day and age of email dependency,  we do not need 100 bells and whistles.   We need functionality.

author: Mother of the Bride!
title: GMail
content:
GMail has lots of nice features that make it easy to use, but there are a few things I wish they would fix!
 1) it would be nice if all your devices would sync so you don't have to delete unwanted emails on each device.
2) the signature feature should be placed at the end of each email, even if it is in grouped feed.
3) the notifications re: unread emails should refresh daily instead of using an all time count. It doesn't motivate me to check email with a huge number, but if each day it reset, I'd know I have new mail.
I hope Google reads these reviews!

author: dougkozar
title: It\'s OK
content:
I\'m looking for an all-in-one mail app for my iPhone. Tried NotionAI last year and was simply not adequate and ready for prime-time. I then moved over to Spark which was very good and had most of the bells and whistles you would want in an AI1 mail app. It just lacked comprehensiveness and reliable syncing capabilities between the iPhone, iWatch, and MacBook versions -- to many indicators of \"unread\" messages across the 3 devices when the messages were, in fact, read...

So I am trying the gmail app but it simply does not send screen notifications to my iPhone when locked or to my iWatch,

I think the desired app is just not yet on the market to make AI1 emailing a reality.

Still looking...

author: msterryinMontana
title: Threaded email HATE
content: I've been using this app for years and I just hate when they join all emails on a subject together. If one of them comes from a no reply return address it's extremely difficult to continue the "conversation". It also shows only the HTML code, not HTML so it's very difficult to read. It will not allow a copy and paste so you could change the reply address to the correct one. There should be a setting to either separate the individual emails or to not use the threaded conversations. I just wasted 2 hours just to reply to an email with an order number. Why can't they leave my emails alone so I can reply as I want and not have to figure out a threaded email with no html? I DON'T WANT them to put all emails on a subject into one. It doesn't work for me. It's enough to make me just give up Gmail and use some other email service. The other Gmail app says it also uses "threaded conversations". I know which emails refer to each other, I don't need you deciding for me, messing my emails up and making them nearly impossible to read in the process.

author: Jen54
title: Are you kidding me??
content:
There are 2 huge things wrong with the gmail app that 80% of users hate and yet google continues to do updates on the app and completely ignore these 2 very crucial problems. 

1- It doesn\'t allow you to turn off conversation view. It is awful. It\'s crazy to me that Google won\'t listen to thousands of complaints regarding this. In my job I will use the same subject line in many different conversations. So then it groups all of those emails together.  And many times important messages get lost in these lengthy \"conversations\".  

2- It won\'t allow you to add your signature right after your message.  It adds it at the very bottom of the string of conversations making it pointless to have a signature at all.  Someone would have to scroll down to the bottom of the whole conversation to see your signature.  Who would do that??  How does google not see this as a problem?  Do they mean to put the signature at the very bottom or is this a glitch?

Google stop wasting time on STUPID updates like this last one and actually step up to the plate and fix the real problems.

author: Financialadventure
title: Current version is an unstable build and crashes all the time
content:
I love gmail and I have been using it for more than a decade.  This app was a star performer.  I only wish they added the feature to filter messages like these like they have in their desktop version, because it is commonly used to avoid spam and put emails in filters/folders. 

Now here is the main problem with the current release 
I am experiencing.  Until 8/1/17, gmail was rock solid òn my ipad 4 and never crashed.  Now (8/15/17) gmail crashes all the time, especially when I do things like writing and sending an email or switching between my folders.  I go from writing an email to watching the app close to then if i double tap my ipad to see a list of running apps to i can sometimes see it is still in the background.  If it is still running it has lost some of my information, ortherwise  the app crashes hard and the app is no longer running.  Google, Please roll back one release to a more stable version that existed prior to 1 August 17.

author: Christopher Murray
title: Yet another pointless update this week!
content:
This will be my last review on this app as there's obviously no point in writing these because the folks at Google don't read them!
Still no changes on the following suggestions --

- emails are no longer modified to fit the screen or for mobile viewing, e.g. with some newsletters and subscribed emails, one must utilize pinch and zoom unlike before where they would easily fit the screen for easier reading, or the iOS device must be turned sideways. 

- why can't emails in the trash folder be deleted? I don't want to select 'Empty Trash Now' to delete all my trashed emails. What if I only wish to delete one or a couple emails and keep the rest?  

It's obvious that Google intends for this app to become more like their Inbox app so that they can eventually merge it with Inbox or get rid of the Gmail app altogether. 
For me, going back to Apple Mail!

Edit - after innumerable updates, the following issues still remain: emails still cannot be deleted from the Trash folder.  Why I cannot have control of deleting my own emails from the Trash folder is beyond me!  Second issue: it would appear the Fit To Modify feature is now forever gone as some of my emails cannot even be read as the text/font is too small. 
Really nothing to note or see here — returning to Apple Mail which seems to be suiting my emailing needs just fine, plus added bonus, my emails aren't scanned and read by Apple (privacy is respected there)!

Edit – so after the newest update (08/10/17), one still cannot delete individual emails in their trash folder.  Why?  It's my email, but apparently Google doesn't seem to think so, and instead controls MY email.  
I also see that another issue hasn't been fixed - some emails not fitted for the iOS screen. 
Obviously nothing of worth to see here therefore returning to Apple/iCloud Mail which has been meeting my email needs more than adequately since switching over.

title: Attachments
content: My main complaint is that from within the app you can only attach files from your photos or Google Drive--not iCloud Drive. Everything I want to attach is in iCloud, I don't use Google Drive. It's really annoying to have to go through the iCloud or Pages app to write Gmail account emails with attachments (and you cant reply in an email chain with an attachment located in iCloud--you can only start a new chain). Only Google seems to have this aversion to letting users access iCloud, which in my case is integrated with my computer's hard drive and so contains everything.

author: jbh615
title: Not very well done
content:
I enjoy most of the available Google services, this being their top app. It used to work with whatever files and services my phone has; local file or the Apple drive, but no more. When I send a file, I want to send the file, not help advertise GDocs with some crap link to a service that should be shut off, like Google+. We see it. We know. Stop it. No one wants it. Sending a link instead of the file is not what anyone needs. I've now moved my files to a place that both Apple Mail Gmail can access, and will stop using GDocs. I want to edit my resume and send it, not hype a less than useful service from google.
Furthermore, they dropped access to the Apple drive to force you to use their own Gdrive. This makes it less that useful, and forces me to use their web app to email my files, until I move off of this service altogether. Can't wait to stop using Gmail. Just a waste of my time. This makes Yahoo Mail look like a better option for my secondary mail service. And don't get me started on the garbage they force feed you on Android devices. Garbage in the cloud raining down into a device that never receives an OS update... what are they trying to pull here?! Avoid this service and Android. It's not worth the hype.

content:

author: rpboz
title: Drives Me Crazy
content:
I love having gmail on my iPhone. I love being able to access my work from any where, truly this app makes my life St much easier than it would otherwise be. 

The problem comes from not being able to access my groups. When I go to send an email, the app does not recognize any group I have created. This means digging for an old email (providing I have one which I don\'t always have one not even in my trash) going into it and copying and pasting all the addresses. Unfortunately, as I said, this isn\'t always possible. 

From someone who\'s job revolves around groups on email, this can make using the app very tedious and frustrating. There is nothing Apple can do about it, it has to come from google. 

If they would fix this issue, this would be a five star rating.

author: cobblestone47
title: Email is mail!
content:
It is a good app!  It works fine for me.  If it didn\'t , I would not use it!  I don\'t have to walk to the mailbox to get it; rain or shine.
I could do without the trash mail, ads, porn, and stuff from idiots trying to make a fast buck.  I\'m over 70 years old and don\'t need a date with a skimpily dressed Russian teenager or any underage female from any country!  The two worst inventions are computers and cell phones!  They are both pretty good when they function like intended.  However, its the criminals and idiots in the world that will not leave you in peace but drive you to pieces trying to scam and steal from you without any physical contact!  Let them come to my door; I have a shotgun for those criminals stupid enough.  I just wish the programmers could develop a nuclear style application that would be like a bloodhound to seek out the criminal elements in this computer world to meltdown and destroy their computers and cell phones so that we could have peace.  Naive knuckleheads still use their cell phones while driving and walking!  I\'ve been run off sidewalks as well as highways and byways.  It\'s not fun dodging other vehicles coming at you head on!  
I may have gotten a little off topic but, just so you know, your app works okay for me; it could always use some improvement!
Have a good day!  Now quit bothering me about a review or survey.

author: Mg2012/11-20
title: Step backwards..
content:
The latest update has left me feeling frustrated.

I find I am not getting notifications consistently, accounts listed as important have either lost their important flag or the app has failed to identify them as such and I am not getting notified in a timely manner. 

There is also the annoying problem of being notified of messages which have already been read. Leaving you to think you have received a new message when you haven\'t . The benefit of Gmail was that it was much quicker than the Mail client app on my iPad, now...it is a wash...  I hope these issues are resolved soon.

It\'s now 2017...
And it\'s come full circle. Back to not getting notifications after the newest update... message threads are often out of order. 

It would be very helpful if when an update is released instead of stating \"bug fixes\" , developers would state the bugs they have addressed in the rev being released.  Dropping my rating. The app causes more problems for me than it solves. Apple mail more reliable at this point.

author: *please insert name here*
title: Other than one small thing, no complaints
content:
Forgot how atrocious iphone\'s native email app was, so I\'m extrememly happy there is a separate gmail option!

It\'s a welcome break from the monotone pallet, and the app\'s operation is very close to Android\'s version--I can delete one or more emails by clicking the left circle, click the star to flag, save to another folder/heading, and check said folders by clicking the menu on the upper left. ALL WITHOUT GOING INTO THE INDIVIDUAL EMAILS. This app also does not try to add extra calendars from the email accounts loaded and screw up my schedule the way the iphone app does (or double up on ones already there).

Only complaint is swiping extreme left or right gives you \"archive\" instead of \"delete\". Aside from not needing two ways to do something I don\'t have a use for, no issues in the week or so I\'ve been using this app.

author: Kane8831
title: Easy access to gmail
content:
I use the gmail app on the ipad, which at time is more responsive than the web version. While it is understood that the web UI has all the capabilities, the ipad app has the core to make it useful. 

My only reason for 4 stars is that the app tends to crash if you delete too many emails too quickly, or try to do an attachment, or try to open the Google Calendar app from within Google Mail. (Hopefully there is an auto crash reporting in background to improve this for the future).

Missing features I would love to see, would include the ability to swipe on a message a different direction to \"move\" it to a folder or apply a \"label\".  And the ability to access other cloud drives for attachments, although I will not hold my breath on this one, since Google likes to keep resources in the family.  And maye not a feature, but I wish the same feature set was availalble on the iphone to make using the two devices a similar experience.

Outside of that, the new Google Mail app is now my \"go to\" app for email.

author: P4PA515
title: Gmail App For iPad Need Some Weak AI
content:
You may expect the gmail app to work better than the web browser application on a PC/Mac.  Sadly this is not the case. The browser app works better than the app-store app and the browser app --- because it insist on running in mobile mode --- does not work as well as the browser app on a desktop/laptop computer.

This is generally the case, and no mystery here since laptops/desktops are still way ahead of touch.

Once Moore's Law clicks over again and speech to/from text actually arrives and replaces the kbd/screen then we will have the Next-Gen of computer OSes that allow us to use them with natural language.

I do not think this will equate with strong AI but many users will most likely think it does.

author: terrilee_nc
title: Why can't I create calendar events from mail??
content: Gmail app is organized and easy to use BUT I can't unreservedly rec this app, because of a huge frustration:  I can't create events in my calendar from an email!!  I've used Gmail desktop almost as long as it's existed, and Gmail app as long as I've had an iPhone. Gmail is superior to the native Apple mail app in SO many ways, mainly the auto-sorted inbox folders. The native iPhone mail app just throws all the good and junk mail into one big bin and it's a time consuming mess to slog through - BUT if I want to quickly create an event from an email, I have to go find the message in the Apple app and create an event that way. On the Gmail desktop, I can create events. A mail app should be a productivity tool, not a barrier.

author: NickME646
title: Fix these two things, please?
content: 1. When you hit Reply All, it only includes addresses in the To field; it doesn't include addresses in the CC field. In web/desktop Gmail and in every other email client, Reply All includes the CC addresses. 2. When composing an email, there's no way to browse and insert addresses from my Gmail address book. This is a huge omission. I have a lot of contacts in Gmail and I can't remember all of them. It also means that I can't insert groups of contacts that I've created in web Gmail (e.g. work, family, friends, etc). 3. There are other issues as well, but these two are huge and I would appreciate it so much if you could fix them. Thanks!

author: Mooolah
title: Easy to use, could be better
content:
The app is easier to use Gmail functions like attachments from Google drive and I do like the look of the interface. However, I use it on my iPhone and have come to wish it had these features in comparison to the mail app on iPhone: 

- all mail for inbox messages only from all the accounts on your phone

It has an All Mail feature that gives you everything under the sun, which is not what is immediately important. I have 3+ mail accounts and in order to check each inbox in have to make a separate click. That should be easier 

- make it easier to swipe to delete

I don\'t have a desire to \"archive\" junk mail that I\'ll never use. I\'d like to just swipe left or right and delete it. It does have a feature where you can click on the mail, then it will give you the option to make multiple selections, then you have to click the trash icon. I agree with another user that it should be easier to delete email. I\'d like to swipe left or right to delete.

author: Kendall the girl
title: Great interface but drafts gotta GO
content:
This app is great for folks who use multiple gmail accounts. The interface allows you to switch mailboxes seamlessly!

I do not like that the app displays multiple drafts of an email I\'ve written and already sent to a recipient. 

I do not actively save these drafts when I\'m writing, but it appears the app will do this for me anyway, either because I\'m typing slowly or because I\'m multitasking by going back and forth between other apps mid email composition. 

When I\'m looking through email conversations I want to be able to see the actual received/sent emails, not the 25 drafts the app saved for me. It clogs up the conversation, making it much harder for me to locate the exact email I\'m trying to find.

After less than ten minutes with it I\'ve deleted the app and gone back to Apple\'s built in Mail app. A fifth of the screen space of every line previewing the mail is taken up with a giant circle letting me know the first letter of the name of who has emailed me? author: BridgeLover
title: No option to prevent loading images
content:
Updates noted below. Still 1 star because it\'s worse than it had previously been. 

The big update has regressed several things, and the smaller updates still have not addressed these:

First, the emails now *automatically* load images. I want the option back to choose when to load images for emails that I have not said to always load.

(FIXED)Second, the when opening the app, it no longer remembers the last view, and only opens to the \"Unread\" view. I want it back to open to my Inbox: Everything .

Third, the swiping function for archiving emails needs to have a stop, such that a short swipe has you tap the icon to archive or delete, and a long swipe performs the action without the additional tapping of the icon.

(FIXED)Fourth, there is no longer the ability to edit quoted text when replying or forwarding.

(FIXED) Fifth, links now open in Safari, not in a mini browser in app?

(FIXED) Sixth, no rich text in compose.

author: FireSmack

content: Google believes it\'s OK not to honor your setting to prevent  automatically loading remote images. Because of that, spammers and hackers know you when you read their emails. One star until this stupid bug is fixed.

author: fjpoblam
title: Better sometimes than base mail app. But WARNING!
content:
WARNING! There is a fake pop-up lurking around (BTDT) urging you to download a "new" version of this app. NOTICE that it directs you to a URL labeled "goo DOT le dot com" ( notice the dot after the "goo"?) DON'T do it! (We didn't, but just thought I'd let you know.)

This app sometimes (only sometimes) updates more quickly than the base mail app. It is also helpful for marking Spam items as NOT Spam, and for marking Inbox items as Spam.

It is a bit more efficient (finger-wise) at emptying the Spam and Trash boxes for those of you (like me) who are anal enough to keep those two scrupulously empty.

Con: sometimes it fails to delete an email in Trash even though you specifically said, "Delete this sucker". You may have to even sign on via the browser and delete the email. BTDT

author: cygnl7
title: When it works it\'s great. Just stop locking up.
content:
I came back to the Gmail app after trying a couple of other clients and running into stability issues. This app is still lacking a few essential features other clients have (just read some of the other reviews) but I\'d be ok with those shortcomings if it meant a fast, solid experience.

Alas, this is not the case. The Gmail app locks up a number of times a day now. Killing it and restarting doesn\'t help much. If I can manage to kill, restart, and switch accounts quickly enough I can keep it from freezing. Maybe it\'s specific to a certain attribute of emails I\'m receiving and it takes the app a bit to come across that? I don\'t know. All I know is I came back to the Gmail app because it used to be rock solid for me but it\'s not anymore, and very frustratingly so.

author: dori24601
title: Hate it
content: I'm sorry, but I HATE the newest version of the gmail app. This was my "go to" place for all of my email (gmail and outlook) because it was perfect (well, there was one complaint: the "folders" I have set up under each email address weren't accessed just by clicking on that email address; I did hate scrolling through every folder under every address to find the one I needed, but nothing is truly perfect, now, is it?). Unfortunately, now, I really hate this app. I haven't tried yet, but I am going to see if I can get my old version back.  I loved the fact that I could select several unopened emails at a time and either move them to the correct folder or delete them all at once. I loved the ease of moving my emails into my folders. I loved the intuitive ability gmail had to guess which folder I wanted to move my email into. Now, when I tap the file folder in the app, my email DISAPPEARS. It goes into an archive somewhere, but I can't find THAT folder on my phone. Is there a visible "archive" folder? Additionally, when I want to ensure my email goes into the correct folder, I have to complete a multi-step process: hit the "..." hit the "more" find and hit the "move". I'm thinking those were the steps, it's so complicated now I can't even remember. Essentially, you did make the app cleaner and more contemporary, but it's not convenient at all. Just my two cents. PS I am probably going to send this rant every time I try to use the stupid app to organize my email from my phone... until I find that old version and reinstall it! lol

content:
First and foremost, no printing of emails.  I have to use the web interface to do it.  Why have an app if I have to go to the web for essential functions?  Second, why haven't you implemented a feature to customize actions on an email based on which way I swipe?  For example, swipe right=mark as read or un-read toggle.  Swipe left=delete.  Microsoft's Outlook OWA has this.  Saves a ton of time. 

When this app came out I stayed with the original gmail app for quite some time because it had a lot more functionality (like printing and connecting with other apps).  Now you've started removing features.  I'm now removing this app until you put back the essential features.  The interface is nice and all, but seriously on the glaring lack of base functionality?

author: Alpesh P
title: Critical functionality lost
content:
Update July 2017
Recent updates lost short-lived ability to dial phone numbers directly from email message. Back to tedious copy-paste-call. 

The reply suggestions are interesting though. Saves about 10 seconds but I'm not sure how I feel knowing that google is parsing and understanding all of my email content. 

Update. All of a sudden, I can now edit text in forwarded messages...I had not updated the app, this functionality just appeared on its own...just like in google's map app the nearby traffic widget just stopped working on its own one day. Curious. 

Signatures still are not tying into my web gmail settings and are completely unusable for aliases and HTML formatted signatures...which I need for my business use. At least give this functionality to your paying customers!

Also realizing how much I miss the reply & forward buttons at the top of the screen in gmail 4.x. 

Many improvements in gmail 5.x but they do not make up for lost features. 

Original review:

BEWARE. gmail 5.x is simply rebranded inbox and lacks the same critical features, namely:

-horrendous signature handling. No HTML signatures. No alias specific signatures.

(fixed)-message forwarding limitations. Cannot edit forwarded message. 

There's a longer list of reasons I hadn't switched from gmail 4.x to inbox but those are more preferences as opposed to critical requirements to do my work. 

The 5.x search improvement is nice but irrelevant since I can no longer use the gmail app for work so I'm now searching for a new mail app for the first time since a native gmail app was introduced.

Disappointed.

author: SyNice
title: Awesome App
content: I don\'t like having my emails categorized by an AUTOBOT! I would prefer to categorize my own emails! I miss important info because it\'s categorized as Social or one of the other irritating categories! I tried changing the categories and then mail started disappearing! Can\'t even get mailings from Kroger anymore!!!! Plus, even the notifications from calendar don\'t come to the INBOX!! The go straight to a category!! I can only see the categories of i open them!! author: Gma loves vampires
title: Pretty good, BUT..
content:
Where are my emails from say, 3 mos ago?? It used to be that I could scroll down to my very First email! I had emails SAVED from 3 years ago! Now I don't see them Anywhere!!! Now when I scroll it only shows for 2-3 months! I admit to being quite technology challenged, so is this somehow an oversight on my part?? Btw, isn't there supposed to be an Archive?? Where is it??

My only complaint other than the previous one above is, I've Accidentally deleted emails at least twice now by sliding the email to the side!! WTH?? The first time it happened, I wasn't quite sure wth happened! When it happened again a couple of weeks ? later, I saw how that works. Unlike when you Intentionally delete an email, there is no option to undo. I've noticed also that Gmail has become extremely touch sensitive. I've lost an email more than once by scrolling too far or whatever. The same thing happens in the Google search app. (which I use more by far than any other app in my iPhone) The Google apps, particularly Gmail seem to be getting less user friendly imo.

July 4th ~ I'm really getting sick of Accidentally losing emails while scrolling!! It has happened at least 6-7 times now! It's ridiculous how easily unread (or Any) emails are archived with no chance to undo! Each time this has happened, I've No idea which email I've inadvertently archived!! (It happens so Fast and unexpectedly!) How pray tell can you check archived emails?? I see no way to do this! If you won't change your too touch sensitive archiving system, please at least give us a chance to undo an archiving.

author: MPD_81
title: Still not listening to customer feedbacks!
content:
Google does so many things right, it is incomprehensible that they would leave their own email app to the town drunk during creation!

Worst feature is that it groups emails into threads.  You cannot change this even though they gave the capability to their web-based version YEARS ago!

Another problem is security.  They do not provide any form of security in order to access the app (like TouchID).

Finally, they do not offer any quick options when a notification pops up (other than Trash & Dismiss).  Where is Mark as Read, reply, etc etc....even the stock iOS-Mail app gives those options!

Google, you really f'd this one up!  I'll continue using the plethora of other apps you did a good job on, but I have had it with your email apps (both this and the other one).

Mail has been a really useful mobile app for me on my phone and I would recommend it to anyone who has too much spam mail and doesn't want to read. Make sure to enable notifications if you want the non-spam mail. 
Overall this is a practical but useful app for your gmail accounts.

Update 6/29/17: WHY in the actual F*** does gmail continue to insist on using the browser preview? I want to open links directly into safari. Reduced to two stars until this is fixed. It's useless.

My biggest complaint is that the browser preview cannot be disabled. Every time I click on a link it goes to gmails browser instead of safari. It's limited in its capability and annoying if I'm already logged into a particular website in safari. Gmail also glitches out sometimes if you click on an email notification banner, it will not open the email and has to be force closed or go back to the primary inbox. Other than that, I love that promotional and social email is separate from my primary email, the system works very well and i wish it was done on more email clients, like spark.

author: Omanoff
title: Good functionality and integration overall
content:
I read some of the other reviews. I think Gmail is a good application I do not use inbox on my iPhone. Are use my mobile app more than the desktop app and I do wish all the functionality and the desktop was on the mobile app such as  being able to make a message important on the mobile app. 

Also the contact synchronization I think could be improved because sometimes it seems that either Facebook or Google wiped out my information while consolidating it. I'm not sure exactly what happens.

I like the labeling in Gmail and I used to keep many important documents there and search I also backed them up but now that Gmail makes you pay for more data I cannot keep as much information for me the searching is an important component of my email environment. I've been able to figure out the searching pretty much with the use of the labels. 

I've given up trying to have an empty inbox now I just distinguish between important and everything I try to unsubscribe but it's just too much like an ocean that can't be stopped so right now Gmail is the best email application I found I came from a corporate environment which we use Outlook and I went from outlook to Gmail and I pretty much stay there.

I do know that Big Brother is watching and everything I do is categorized according to data and marketing preferences and I don't like that.

I am trying to make the move from Google to other encrypted and safe browsers but I haven't done it yet because the Google search engine is so good.

author: Christopher Murray
title: Yet another pointless update this week!
content:
This will be my last review on this app as there\'s obviously no point in writing these because the folks at Google don\'t read them!
Still no changes on the following suggestions --

- emails are no longer modified to fit the screen or for mobile viewing, e.g. with some newsletters and subscribed emails, one must utilize pinch and zoom unlike before where they would easily fit the screen for easier reading, or the iOS device must be turned sideways. 

- why can\'t emails in the trash folder be deleted? I don\'t want to select \'Empty Trash Now\' to delete all my trashed emails. What if I only wish to delete one or a couple emails and keep the rest?  

It\'s obvious that Google intends for this app to become more like their Inbox app so that they can eventually merge it with Inbox or get rid of the Gmail app altogether. 
For me, going back to Apple Mail!

Edit - after innumerable updates, the following issues still remain: emails still cannot be deleted from the Trash folder.  Why I cannot have control of deleting my own emails from the Trash folder is beyond me!  Second issue: it would appear the Fit To Modify feature is now forever gone as some of my emails cannot even be read as the text/font is too small. 
Really nothing to note or see here — returning to Apple Mail which seems to be suiting my emailing needs just fine, plus added bonus, my emails aren\'t scanned and read by Apple (privacy is respected there)!

01/24/17 - Are we EVER going to have the ability to print again????  This is a huge flaw in the current design.

12/20/16 - Once again another WORTHLESS update since you STILL CAN\'T PRINT!!!!  I would think this would be considered a basic function, guess not in your world.  Also still can\'t change profile picture which is yet another feature you have axed---WHY???

12/09/16 - Yet another WORTHLESS update.  Still can\'t PRINT which is a huge problem for me.  PLEASE do us all a favor and back all this s**t out and go back to previous version.

12/02/16 - Just put on the latest update.  Don\'t know how you managed it but WORSE then previous.  Still CAN\'T PRINT!!!  Mail I got prior to update suddenly put in Spam folder, who the H knows why.  So wish I could give a minus rating.  Will hang in awhile longer then, as much as I hate to have to change to another E-Mail will have no choice as this now is basically
unusable!!!!

11/24/16 - Just found can no longer print any of my E-Mails or change profile picture.  When are ya\'ll either going to fix this piece of garbage or better yet back the whole D thing out?????  I would give it a -0 if I could.  You have taken a decent, useful application and made it TOTALLY USELESS!!!!

11/17/16 - Just installed most recent update, still as HORRIBLE as previous. 

If could give a zero I would.  If mail has pictures these don\'t forward, can\'t edit Drafts, can\'t get read mail to close after finished and  on and on and on.  To put it simply, HATE IT!!!! Have tried this about 4 times, same result each time.

author: john15.5woman
title: Can't print emails nor send PDF to iBooks
content: Generally gmail is a good app, but the "improvements" that they made within the past six months, or more,  have taken this app back about 10 years! I used to be able to print out my emails (very important for things such as receipts) - but the developers decided in their "wisdom" that you can't do that any more. I also used to have the ability to save PDF format directly into my iBooks, but for some reason this too they took away. What a hassle! Now I have to send my PDF to Notes and then import it to iBooks. Giving a giant company like Google feedback is nearly impossible, and when you do provide feedback, if they actually see it, then they want you to justify just why you want something. Really? Google you are too big for your britches! LISTEN to your customers!

author: Disappointed pet mama
title: Horrible new appearance and "improvements"
content:
I want my email to look like an inbox, not social media. The busy, new, swarming with colors and pictures and logos inbox is not an improvement. Please either put it back or have style options so those of us who prefer not to be assaulted with stylizing every time we check email have an option. Up until this update I have preferred using the gmail app, however with the new "improvements" apple's included mail app is looking a lot more appealing.
  
Update: just when it seemed like they couldn't duck it up anymore, they found a way. They added annoying little reply option buttons, which at least you can turn off and this horrible blown up summary of a piece of email before you get to the actual email for things with calendar info or tracking that doesn't seem disable-able.  Google, haven't you ever heard the expression "if it's not broken, don't fix it"?!?

author: KeanuMadonna
title: More bloated junk from Google
content:
Another antiquated, buggy, and bloated crap-app from Google, complete with the requisite abhorrently inconsistent UX/design/interface.

And Google is the ONLY email/etc. "service provider" that refuses to let its users BLOCK senders -- their email address, IP address, etc.

The "block" option in DESKTOP-ONLY Gmail is merely a filter that sends crap to your Spam folder; Gmail accounts already get inundated with ungodly amounts of crap as it stands -- malware, phishing scams, viruses, spyware, you name it.

It's a blatant testament that the ONLY thing Google cares about is obtaining as much information about you, and selling it.

You're the only company on the planet and it should stay that way. Maybe Apple decides THEY are the only company on the planet and yanks all your apps from their platform. Wouldn't that be a laugh? All of this is counterproductive and a disservice to users of Gmail. Your little middle finger to every other competitor in your field only hurts your users, NOT your competition. Case and point: I deleted your mail app from all of my devices. Fix it and I'll reinstall it. See, I'm not unreasonable. Are you?

author: wlorenzo
title: Please fix notifications. Sync flags. Add ability to snooze an email.
content:
Once I've "read" the email on any device, the notifications on my notification screen and lockscreen should go away automatically, similar to other messaging apps (Apple Mail, iMessage). 
Also:
- support all Desktop flag types for starred items (blue star, red star, question mark, etc)
- ability to mark messages as read from notification banner

Sync flag types from web gmail.com to iOS Gmail app

Snooze an email:
Add the ability to snooze an email to set a reminder for the future, similar to Google Inbox

So, they added the feature and now they\'re ignoring it.  Pathetic.  Also, there is no way to disable pictures from displaying in email, which means more bandwidth use and higher exploit risk from pic decoders. Conclusion for gmail alternatives:  Alto for typical email users and Newton Mail for business class users.  gMail, I want to come back, but I suppose you have to weigh lost users like me against the privacy clueless suckers who will use gMail anyway.

author: cpoagsc
title: No Connection errors
content:
This app is completely useless for me on iPhone. It never connects and reports \"no connection\" at the bottom of the screen while every other app on the phone has no trouble connecting. It is only this app that has problems connecting. I\'ve followed all help and forum posts I\'ve found and they\'re pretty useless. I\'ve logged out and back in (sometimes it won\'t even let me log back in, giving me the \"no connection\" error). I\'ve deleted and reinstalled the app many times with no success. And yes, Google, I\'m sure I\'m using the correct password.

Google needs to resolve the \"no connection\" error issue with an update rather than just advising people to check their password or make sure they\'re connected to the internet (when every other app on the device works fine).

author: InsanityTheatre
title: I can\'t swipe through my messages anymore
content:
**review update **

A lot of my previous issues were fixed but now when I click a link it opens in the gmail app instead of in a separate safari window. I usually open emails click the links I need and then go to the next email. Now I have to click a link pop it out of the app then close the window in the ap before I can go to the next email. This issue just occurred. Please fix. Wastes a lot of time!!

I agree with other reviewers this update has a lot of flaws. For me the biggest being I can not swipe between emails to read them. I have to go back to the inbox to select next message. This slows me down immensely. Also easy of use has declined. The swipe to archive/delete shouldn\'t be and/or it should be both (one direction archive one delete). Also I found the ability to select my emails but still not as functional as before, esp because less emails on screen and when I select too many it resets! The color is not great but I could overlook poor visual design if the function was there. The only feature I like on the update is the undo feature. However I have downgraded to the previous version until gmail updates and fixes these issues.

And now if you swipe to either the right or left it archives the emails and maybe I'm an idiot, but I can not figure out how to get to my archived emails to get rid ones I added on accident. If I'm dumb and just not seeing it, I can accept that, but then you have to remember that this is supposed to be an app even an idiot can use. So you know keep that in mind Google. Over all not happy with the changes to the newest version, I wish I had never updated it. I have a stop feeling I won't be using my gmail on my phone any more. Two stars cause it still gets emails I guess.

author: AdMajoremBlog
title: Love Gmail, hate this app
content:
Gmail has been a boon to my personal-professional life. It\'s organized, it\'s secure, it\'s easy and the @gmail domain is also a good enough brand to put next to my name. But when it comes to this app, none of the above matters. 

It won\'t let me separate a string of emails, forcing me to keep them in a \"conversation\" which has led me, embarrassingly, to reply to a stale message, getting out of synch with said \"conversation\". Why can\'t I separate those emails as I do on the website?

It won\'t communicate spam or security warnings, which led me to open a phishing attachment via my phone. I\'m embarrassed to admit I was fooled, but angry to see later that the web version of the same email showed a big red warning flag advising me of the danger. No such warning on this app. 

I\'ve also noticed emails don\'t arrive in real-time on the app. An email might show up on the web version but not the app. 

In short: I\'m keeping my gmail account but using this app only to see \"what\'s going on\", waiting until I\'m in front of the web version to actually accomplish things.

author: Kindlejunkie
title: Really would like a fix for aliases in gmail
content:
If I send a doc from my ipad the only choice I have is my actual real gmail account - the aliases are not choices - while they are all choices if no document is attached - plain vanilla email. I have one important contact who absolutely cannot receive these documents - from my "real" gmail address - she can only receive from the alias I use for this group of people.  Others in this group, have to search multiple emails of mine to find this or that document I have sent, which is also a pain.

Yes, there is a clunky workaround for this.  If I have already sent this document to others, I can go directly to the gmail app and locate and attach recent attachments.  I do appreciate this fairly new feature!  And, I have also submitted this feature request to Apple, as I do not know exactly who can fix it best.  Thank you !!!!  meg at pacificwildlifecare dot org - my best alias.

author: Revtrin
title: Missing Basic Features
content:
It\'s easy for emails to pile up and the easiest way to address this is to mark all emails as read. It\'s a basic feature of most if not all email apps, except for Gmail that is. This major feature is missing from Gmail and it means I have to remember to do this when I\'m at my computer. For a premiere email service to not have such a basic feature is inexcusable. I don\'t want to import my Gmail with Apple mail so I\'m stuck with this until Google gets smart and decides to fix this. 

Another basic feature missing is an unread mail category. So I can\'t even group them together to go through unread emails. Again there\'s no excuse for not having this feature. 

Please add these basic email functions Google.

Finally, not having the option to turn off conversations view is just impractical. This is not a great way to organize conversations and I hate it but if you use this app you\'re stuck and have no choice but to live with it. 

I use this for my business so I deliberately keep it for separate use from Apple mail but that may no longer be possible. 

And don\'t get me started in Google \"help.\" It\'s anything but helpful. I like emails and phone numbers. It\'s fine for people who have the time to hunt for their own answers but for the rest of us who have a life, I want to quickly and easily be able to find contact info to get in touch with a human being. Google is better at this than most but it\'s still hard to locate.

author: Newsless in Seattle
title: Personal emails are not private
content:
The latest update (Smart Replies) that suggests responses after reading your personal emails is a stark reminder that nothing in your email is private. Your personal, intimate thoughts are then sold to merchants to try to sell you stuff. The primary value of Smart Replies is that it is a reminder that google is watching, analyzing and recording your every keystroke. I now realize Sting's song "I'll be watching you" actually predicted google. Their EULA might be lifted from this song.

And your very analyzed email gives you ads based on your personal communications. (Don't we all love merchants listening in to our daily thoughts to friends and family so they can try to sell us stuff?) But they do deliver your email, so 2 stars... I think other email apps can do that too (and some try to let you be private). No need to steal privacy when we willingly surrender/sell it for a popular email app.

author: Multi Curren$y
title: Really awesome but still room for improvement
content:
Overall a great app which I've come to love and recommend to my circles. That said there's still a few things from the native mail and inbox that I think should be merged into gmail for really awesome experience. 

My suggestions would be:

1. Allow us to select which direction the swipes go/mean. So left for delete, right for mark as unread/read 
2. 3D Touch for emails 
3. Things like tracking numbers, travel etc just show the details in the app and not have is copy/paste the tracking code to UPS/FedEx etc 
4. Same idea with travel plans similar to inbox. 
5. Snooze/mute notifications. I get every Friday about 500 notifications from our server and it blows up Notification Center. If I can snooze those that would be great. 

Overall it's awesome, keep it up!

All in all I love this application and my life is better because of it. I'm so glad they repeatedly asked me to review it to the point that I gave in out of boredom. 

And if you are a Buzzfeed writer looking for funny reviews for a list article than feel free to use this I think it's certainly not my best work but what are you gonna do amirite?

Dear Buzzfeed readers if you enjoyed this style of humor than pop on over to youtube.com/barrettlarkinfo for stuff written in more than 5 minutes.

author: Newsless in Seattle
title: Nothing even pretends to be private here
content:
The latest update (Smart Replies) that suggests responses after reading your private email is a stark reminder that nothing in your email is private. Actually it\'s primary value lies in the fact that it is a good, daily reminder that you should remember that google is watching, analyzing and recording your every keystroke. Is it creepy? Yes, but...  hmmm... no, It\'s just creepy. I now realize Sting\'s song \"I\'ll be watching you\" actually predicted google. Their EULA might be lifted from this song.

And your very analyzed email gives you ads based on your personal communications. (Don\'t we all love merchants listening in to our daily thoughts to friends and family so they can try to sell us stuff?) But they do deliver your email, so 2 stars... I think other email apps can do that too (and some try to let you be private). No need to steal privacy when we willingly surrender/sell it for a popular email app.

title: Good
content:
Would love to see
>Apple Watch app
>import other email for school and work to have a unified inbox
>able to view contacts/calendar
>ability to see if spam folder has emails (notification by spam folder
>can only AirPrint attachments, would like to be able to print emails too (cloud and AirPrint)

I think it's confusing to have 2 different email apps, I do like the reminder feature in inbox
